title: Dating and MG

content: The big question I always get is, “How do you date with MG?”
Ahhh … I don’t even know how to start.
Any person who has MG, or any chronic illness, would likely agree our first thought after diagnosis is about who’s going to want to be with me, and spend their life with someone who’s sick?
I spent months thinking about how my future will look. I was single and 26. Only dark thoughts came to my mind after such a huge diagnosis. Cancer + a chronic muscle illness.
I thought: “Why me? I’m so young!”

One of the hardest treatments we go through is long-term steroids. They alter your entire system. Weight gain, anxiety, depression, insomnia, moon face … the list goes on. How are you supposed to go on dates while dealing with all of that?
It’s a lot. The mental toll of this disease is a lot.
Little by little, I started therapy. It took me time to accept that my life is this way now. I’m on steroids. I have an illness. I don’t want this to stop me.

content: I kept telling myself I’m too young to give up. I still deserve to love and be loved. And I think you say the same thing.
Therapy helped me immensely. Along with my physiotherapy exercises, talking about my journey online gave me more confidence.

About 10 months after my diagnosis, I went on a date. I was so self-conscious about how much my appearance had changed and how much I didn’t feel like myself. But I wanted to go. On my way to the restaurant, I wondered if I should talk about my illness, or even bring it up. There’s no shame in that; that much I knew. And I was proud of how much I’d been through, most of the time by myself.
I did bring it up that night. The date went well, but we didn’t go out again. So all the questions came back to my mind: “Will I ever find love again?”

content: I gave it more time. I focused on myself and on my MG journey. I wanted to be at peace with the illness before welcoming someone into my life, into this new life.

Months later, I found the person for me. A very understanding and supportive man. He knows the limitations of my body, and he helps me without being asked. He goes to my hospital appointments with me, reminds me of my medications every day, and never gets tired of listening to me talk about my illness.
If I were to give dating advice for MGers, I’d say:
Be yourself. The disease isn’t your choice, and it doesn’t define you. The meds you take don’t define you.
Don’t conceal details about your illness. Be straightforward. Be proud of what you’ve been through. The right person will see and admire your strength.
Be patient, but also optimistic. Take time for yourself. Your diagnosis forces you to make changes in your life.

sections.heading: Always put yourself first
content: . You need a partner who understands you might not be able to do ANY household chores for a day, and cooking or doing the dishes might be the only activity your body’s able to do on the weekend. You need plenty of sleep, plenty of love, and care.
Most importantly, know you’re not a burden to anyone. You’re better off alone than with someone who makes you feel that way.
Don’t give up on yourself. Living with MG doesn’t mean your life ends. Embrace the things you can still do. Believe you’ll find a person who wants to do that with you.
Good luck, and remember to be kind to yourself, always.
